did.unittitle: Union League of Philadelphia Committee on Youth Work and Abraham Lincoln Foundation records

bioghist.p: The Union League of Philadelphia was founded in 1862 as a patriotic society to support the policies of President Abraham Lincoln. It evolved to its current identity as a non-sectarian and non-partisan private club. The Committee on Boys Work was established in 1946, holding its first dinner in 1947 to award Good Citizenship medals and certificates to boys, base don recommendations by various charitable agencies. Annual dinners were attended by sports figures, entertainers, and public figures. Winners of the Good Citizenship awards were eligible for scholarships awarded by the Scholarship Committee. established in 1955. In 1971 a non-profit foundation, Boys Work Foundation, was created to raise money for the Scholarship Fund and to make grants to agencies engaged in youth programs. The trustees were appointed by the Union League President and were responsible for accepting contributions and investing funds temporarily, without the intention to establish endowments. In 1986 the names were changed to Committee on Youth Work and Youth Work Foundation in order to include girls as candidates. The Abraham Lincoln Foundation was established in 1995 as a non-profit organization "to maintain and exhibit the Corporation's collections of artwork, Civil War and other books, and other articles of historical importance, to maintain parts of the Union League Building...and to educate students and others in the subjects of art, history and music and other topics."

scopecontent.p: Committee on Youth Work files, 1946-1992, include solicitations, invitations, programs, and other printed material, with some minutes, correspondence, financial and other working files reflecting the different subcommittees: activities, dinner arrangements, door prizes, photographs, membership support, letters and notices, agency coordination, special guests, public relations, speaker, and executive committee. There are also award recipient information cards, 1948-1961, 1973, and 1980-1981, including (variously) name, address, birth date, school, and sponsoring agency. Foundation files, 1971-1989, include agency applications, acknowledgments, and other correspondence, member appointments, minutes, and financial reports. There are three scrapbooks (1978-1980) documenting the Committee on Boys' Work Annual Good Citizenship Awards. The scrap books include printed materials including form letters. invitations and programs etc. Scholarship Fund Committee/Foundation files, 1956-1965, include applications of unsuccessful candidates and correspondence with applicants and others regarding awarding of scholarships. Applications include photograph, name and occupation of parent, family income, home value and mortgage, certificate of agency head, remarks of parent or guardian, certificate of principal or head master, school record and SAT scores. There are also some miscellaneous minutes and other materials. Abraham Lincoln Foundation records include: Trustee, Executive Committee, and Collections Committee minutes, 1997-present; proposal for stewardship of Civil War Museum and Library, 1999-2000; material relating to performance of "While Lincoln Lay Dying," 2000, based on James Tanner manuscript.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
